action.action-desc: Mr. Tiffany introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To require interviews conducted by officers and employees of Federal law enforcement agencies to be recorded.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Federal Accountability in Interviews Reform Act or as the FAIR Act.

section.header: Audio recording of interviews conducted by certain Federal law enforcement officers

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall require the recording, using an electronic audio recording technology, of each interview of a United States citizen who is suspected of having committed a criminal offense conducted by an officer or employee of the Department of Justice in connection with an investigation of a Federal offense or an investigation with respect to which the Department is assisting a State, local, or tribal law enforcement agency.

paragraph.text: The requirements under this section apply with respect to any custodial and non-custodial interview, but do not apply with respect to communication with a confidential informant.
The requirements under this section apply with respect to any interview of a United States citizen outside of the United States conducted by an officer or employee of the Department of Justice.

subsection.text: An officer or employee of the Department of Justice may record an interview described in this section without providing notice to or obtaining consent from the interviewee.
A statement or information obtained during an interview that is not recorded in accordance with this section may not be offered as evidence by the Government in Federal court.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), a recording of an interview described in this section shall be retained for a period of 10 years beginning on the date on which the applicable investigation or any related judicial procedures is finally concluded, whichever is later.

A recording of an interview described in this section shall be retained indefinitely if the content of the recording is related to a judicial proceeding that involves a Federal capital offense or a State capital offense with respect to which the Federal law enforcement officer was assisting the law enforcement agency of the jurisdiction in which the offense occurred.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall finalize rules to carry out this section not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
